item.title: Docs: Adjusting Node Group
item.description:
Describes the operation of adjusting a node group.

Alibaba Cloud

Prerequisites

  • Have permission to edit node groups (node pool).

Operation steps

  1. Log in to the Container Service Management Console and select the cluster in the left navigation bar.
  2. On the cluster list page, click the target cluster name, and then select Node Management > Node Pool in the left navigation bar.
  3. On the node pool list page, click Edit in the Action column of the row where the target node pool is located.
  4. On the Edit Node Pool page, edit the configuration items of the node pool. Node pool optimization mainly focuses on instance specifications and automatic scaling configuration items.
    1. According to the recommended instance rules in the Adjust Node Pool dialog box, select the corresponding instance specification in Instance Specifications.
    2. Make adjustments in the Auto Scaling configuration item based on the recommended automatic scaling, minimum number of nodes, and maximum number of nodes in the Adjust Node Pool dialog box. If cluster automatic scaling is not enabled, please refer to Node automatic scaling to configure.

For more details, please refer to: Edit Node Pool

item.title: Docs: Import Alibaba Cloud Cluster
item.description:
This section describes the detailed steps for importing Alibaba Cloud clusters.

Preconditions

  1. Obtain the Alibaba Cloud Access Key and Access Key Secret and have the following permissions. For the specific application process, please refer to Create Access Key.

    Services Permissions Description
    Cloud Server (ECS) ecs:DescribeDisks
    ecs:DescribeInstances
    ecs:DescribeRegions    		 This permission is required to obtain disk, instance and region information
    Container Service Kubernetes version (CS) cs:DescribeClusterNodePools
    cs:DescribeClusterNodePoolDetail
    cs:DescribeClusters
    cs:DescribeClusterUserKubeconfig
    cs:DescribeClusterNodes    		 This permission is required to obtain the cluster, node group, Node, Kubeconfig and other information

    The permission policy file is described as follows. You can import the policy directly in the Alibaba Cloud console. For details, please refer to [Creating a custom permission policy through script editing mode](https://help.aliyun.com/zh/ram/user- guide/create-a-custom-policy#section-kwn-gu8-48m)

    {
  "Version": "1",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "ecs:DescribeDisks",
        "ecs:DescribeInstances"
        "ecs:DescribeRegions"
      ],
      "Resource": [
        "*"
      ],
      "Condition": {}
    },
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "cs:DescribeClusterNodePools",
        "cs:DescribeClusterNodePoolDetail",
        "cs:DescribeClusters",
        "cs:DescribeClusterUserKubeconfig",
        "cs:DescribeClusterNodes"
      ],
      "Resource": [
        "*"
      ],
      "Condition": {}
    }
  ]
}

  2. Alibaba Cloud Kubernetes cluster Kubeconfig. For cluster versions 1.22 and above, it is recommended to use ACK cluster. For details, please see Container Service Kubernetes version.

  3. Kubeconfig requires the following permissions.

    Resources Permissions Description
    Node List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get node information
    Pod List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Pod information
    Namespace List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Namespace information
    Service List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Service information
    Persistent Volume
    Persistent Volume Claim    		 List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Persistent Volume, Persistent Volume Claim information
    Deployment
    StatefulSet
    DaemonSet

    ReplicaSet
    ReplicationControllers
    		 List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Deployment, StatefulSet, DaemonSet, ReplicaSet , ReplicationContoller information
    Job
    CronJob    		 List
    Get
    Watch    		 Get Job and CronJob information

    The permissions file is as follows:

    apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  name: optimizer
rules:
  - apiGroups:
      - ""
    resources:
      -nodes
      -pods
      -pods/status
      - persistentvolumes
      - persistentvolumeclaims
      - services
      - namespaces
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "apps/v1"
    resources:
      -deployments
      -replicasets
      -replicationcontollers
      - statefulsets
      -daemonsets
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "batch/v1"
    resources:
      - jobs
      - cronjobs
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "storage/v1"
    resources:
      -storageclasses
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch

  4. Prometheus monitoring or Thanos monitoring. This monitoring is used to provide monitoring data for nodes, containers, etc. in the cluster.

Import steps

Add Alibaba Cloud account

  1. Select the Settings menu and select the Cloud Account tab to enter the cloud account management page. By default, this page will display all cloud accounts managed by the platform in pages, including names and corresponding cloud service providers. It also provides an operation bar to facilitate users to perform corresponding operations, as shown in the figure below.

  2. On the cloud account management page, click the Add button to add a cloud account. The interface is as shown below. In this interface, the user enters the cloud account name, selects the corresponding cloud service provider, enters the Access Key and Access Key Secret, and clicks the OK button to complete adding the cloud account. After adding parameters, users can also click the Test Connectivity button to test whether the cloud account is correct. The platform currently supports Alibaba Cloud, which can be selected from the cloud service provider drop-down box. Access Key and Access Key Secret is the account information for accessing the cloud service. Please obtain it from the corresponding cloud service provider.

Add Alibaba Cloud cluster

  1. Select the Settings menu and select the cluster tab to enter the cluster management page. By default, this page will display all clusters managed by the platform in pages, including name, cluster ID, cluster region, Access Token name, corresponding cloud service provider and Prometheus address. It also provides an operation bar to facilitate users to perform corresponding operations. As shown below.

  2. Click the Import Cluster button to pop up the import dialog box, where you can import the cluster. There are 5 steps to import a cluster. Currently, only Alibaba Cloud clusters are supported.

    1. Set Alibaba Cloud access credentials
    2. Connect to the Kubernetes cluster
    3. Connect to Prometheus
    4. View configuration
    5. Complete

  3. The interface for setting Alibaba Cloud access credentials is as shown in the figure below. In the Alibaba Cloud access credentials interface, set the Alibaba Cloud access credentials by using existing credentials. Here, select the Alibaba Cloud account added in Add Alibaba Cloud Account, as shown in the figure below.

  4. After setting the Alibaba Cloud access credentials, click the Next button to enter the page for connecting to the Kubernetes cluster, as shown in the figure below. The platform supports connecting to two types of Kubernetes clusters, including managed clusters and self-built clusters. The Connect Hosting Cluster page is shown in the figure below. Here we choose the managed cluster. The platform automatically obtains the user cluster through the cloud account. The user selects the corresponding cluster through the cluster drop-down box, enters the description field, selects whether to use the API Server private network address, selects whether to automatically refresh KubeConfig and the KubeConfig life cycle. Finally enter the node group label.

  5. The connection page to Prometheus is as shown in the figure below. After the user enters information on this page, click the Next button to enter the view configuration page. The input information details are shown in the table below.

    The parameter description for connecting to Prometheus is as shown in the table:

    Parameters Description
    Whether Thanos If the backend cluster is Thanos, this should be checked.
    Prometheus address Prometheus address, must be accessible.
    Limit access rate If you need the current platform’s access rate to Prometheus, you should check this option.
    Maximum number of concurrencies The maximum number of concurrencies for the platform to access Prometheus.
    Cluster label Cluster label is used to filter the monitoring indicators of the cluster from Prometheus or Thanos
    Cluster tag value Cluster tag value is used to filter the monitoring indicators of the cluster from Prometheus or Thanos

  6. View the configuration page as shown in the figure below. This page displays Alibaba Cloud access credentials, detailed parameters for connecting to the Kubernetes cluster and connecting to the Prometheus cluster, which is convenient for users to confirm. When the user completes the confirmation, click the Import button to enter the completion page.

  7. The completed page is as shown below, and the submission status will be displayed on the page. Click Finish to complete the cluster import.

Next steps

After importing the cluster, wait for a period of time (waiting for the optimization strategy to complete scheduling and execution), and then you can view optimization suggestions for the cluster in multiple dimensions, including:

  • Nodegroup
  • Node
  • GPU node
  • Disk
  • Persistent volume
  • Application

item.title: Docs: Install via kubectl
item.description:
This page describes the detailed steps to install the one-stop cloud native cluster optimization platform (Cluster Optimizer).

Preconditions

  • Mysql database, version 5.7 and above
  • Kubernetes cluster, version 1.22 and above
  • The certificate of the Kubernetes cluster can create the wiseinf-system namespace and create Deployment, ConfigMap, Service and other resources under this namespace

Clone installation script

  1. Open the command line console and clone the installation script to the local computer through the following command.

        git clone https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git

    1. If you use the Gitee warehouse address, you need to replace https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git in the above command with https://gitee.com/wiseinf/setup.git.

    2. The subsequent steps assume that the setup library has been cloned to the user’s home directory. If it has not been cloned to the user’s home directory, the file path in the command needs to be adjusted according to the actual situation.

Deploy application

  1. Create the namespace wiseinf-system through the following command:

        kubectl apply -f ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/namespace.yaml

  2. Create the database optimizer-mysql through the following command, its service name is optimizer-mysql, and can be accessed through the user root and the password Optimizer~:

        kubectl apply -f ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/mysql.yaml

    If you need to bind the database to the specified node, please edit the ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/mysql.yaml file, remove the comments in the affinity field, and modify the value of the value field to Specify the node name as shown below.

      ...
  affinity:
    nodeAffinity:
      requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
        nodeSelectorTerms:
        - matchExpressions:
          - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
            operator: In
            values:
            - ip-10-16-121-100.us-west-1.compute.internal
  ...

  3. Create Deployment optimizer through the following command:

        kubectl apply -f ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml

    Note: If you want to use a deployed database, please see [Use Deployed Database](#Use Deployed Database).

  4. Check whether optimizer is running normally through the following command:

        kubectl get pods -n wiseinf-system

    If it runs normally, you can get output similar to the following, in which the currently running Pod Name is optimizer-5b956655df-gspq6:

        NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE
    optimizer-5b956655df-gspq6 2/2 Running 0 1m

  5. Create port-forward to access the optimizer service through the following command:

        kubectl port-forward svc/optimizer 8000:80 -n wiseinf-system

  6. Open the browser and visit the address http://localhost:8000/.

  7. If you can see the Cluster Optimizer homepage, the application Cluster Optimizer is deployed successfully.

Use deployed database

If you want to use the deployed database and use a new username and password to access Cluster Optimizer, please refer to the following steps:

  1. Execute the mysql command on the command line console to log in to the Mysql database. 127.0.0.1 is the Mysql database host address. You need to replace it with the actual address you use.

        mysql -h127.0.0.1 -uroot

    Note: If you use a remote database, make sure the database is accessible from the Kubernetes cluster.

  2. Create database schema optconf (optimization configuration library) and optdata (optimization database).

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_database.sql

    Note: Please be aware of the risk of data loss. If the optconf library and optdata library already exist in the mysql database, the above script will first delete the library and then create a new library.

  3. Create a new username and password, and set corresponding permissions for them. The username in the script is optimizer and the password is Optimizer~. You can adjust it according to your needs.

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_user.sql

  4. Adjust the database information in the Cluster Optimizer configuration file. Edit the ConfigMap optimizer-conf in the file ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml, and change the dataSource.name value under the configuration items optdata and optconf The user name, user password, database address and port are adjusted to the corresponding information of the Mysql database.

  5. Restart the application and check the log output of Cluster Optimizer (as shown below) to see whether the database configuration information is consistent with your expectations.

    {
    ...
    "optconf": {
        "dataSource": {
            "name": "optimizer:Optimizer~@tcp(127.0.0.1:3306)/optconf?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true\u0026charset=utf8mb4\u0026parseTime=true\u0026loc=Local",
            "maxOpenConns": 10
        }
    },
    "optdata": {
        "dataSource": {
            "name": "optimizer:Optimizer~@tcp(127.0.0.1:3306)/optdata?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true\u0026charset=utf8mb4\u0026parseTime=true\u0026loc=Local",
            "maxOpenConns": 10
        }
    },
    ...
}

    At the same time, also check whether there are any database-related errors. If there are no related errors, it proves that a new database has been used.

Next step: Import the cluster

Next, you can add a cluster and view its related optimization recommendations. For details, see:

  • Import AWS EKS cluster
  • Import Alibaba Cloud Cluster

item.title: Docs: Personal Account Settings
item.description:
Describe operations related to personal account settings.

Preconditions

  • Available only in commercial version.

Update personal information

Click on the user avatar in the top left navigation bar, as shown below. Click Personal Settings on the expanded menu to enter the personal settings page.

On the personal settings page, click the Personal Account tab to view and update personal information, as shown in the figure below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Name User name, required
Last name User last name, optional
First Name Username, optional
Email User email, required
Password User login password, required
Confirm password Confirm user login password, required
Mobile phone number User mobile phone number, required
User role Currently, the system provides two roles: administrator and user. The default is user, which is required
Regional Settings Currently supports Chinese and English locales.

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to modify the personal information.

item.title: Docs: User Management
item.description:
Describe related operations of user management.

Preconditions

*Managing users requires administrator rights. *Available only in commercial version.

View user list

Enter the user management page from Settings --> Users, as shown below.

The user management page will display notification channels in the form of a list. It mainly includes 5 columns:

  • Username: Display user name.
  • Full name: Display user name.
  • Email address: Displays the user’s email address.
  • Phone number: Displays the user’s phone number.
  • Role: Display user role.
  • Operation: Operation bar, including editing, deletion and other operations.

Add user

Click the Add button at the top of the user management page, and the Add User dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Name User name, required
Last name User last name, optional
First Name Username, optional
Email User email, required
Password User login password, required
Confirm password Confirm user login password, required
Mobile phone number User mobile phone number, required
User role Currently, the system provides two roles: administrator and user. The default is user, which is required

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to add the user.

Update user

Click the Edit button in the list of user management pages, and the edit user dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

The specific field names and descriptions are the same as [Add User] (#Add User) and will not be repeated.

Delete user

Click the Delete button on the user management page to delete the user.

Before deleting the user, a deletion confirmation dialog box will pop up. After confirmation, the deletion operation will be performed.

item.title: Docs: Adjustment Node
item.description:
Describes the operation of adjusting nodes.

Alibaba Cloud

Prerequisites

TBD…

item.title: Docs: Cluster Access Account
item.description:
Describes operations related to managing personal cluster access accounts.

Preconditions

  • Available only in commercial version.

View cluster access account

Click on the user avatar in the top left navigation bar, as shown below. Click Personal Settings on the expanded menu to enter the personal settings page.

On the personal settings page, click the Cluster Access Account tab to view and manage the cluster access account, as shown in the figure below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Cluster ID User name, required
Cloud service provider access account User last name, required
Kubeconfig User email address, required
Operation Display user operations

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to modify the personal information.

Add cluster access account

Click the Add button at the top of the cluster access account management page, and the Add Cluster Access Account dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Cluster ID Accessed cluster ID, required
Access Key Access key to access the cloud service provider, required
Access Key Secret Access key to access the cloud service provider, required
Kubeconfig Credentials for accessing Kubernetes, required

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to add the cluster access account.

Note: If you have not added a cluster, the drop-down box of the cluster ID field is empty, the system will report an error, and the cluster access account cannot be added. You can create a cluster access account after [Importing the cluster](/docs/user-guide/import-cluster/].

Update cluster access account

Click the Cluster Access Account button in the list of cluster access account management pages, and the Edit Cluster Access Account dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

The specific field names and descriptions are the same as [Add Cluster Access Account] (#Add Cluster Access Account) and will not be repeated.

Delete cluster access account

Click the Delete button on the cluster access account management page to delete the cluster access account.

Before deleting the cluster access account, a deletion confirmation dialog box will pop up. After confirmation, the deletion operation will be performed.

item.title: Docs: Import AWS EKS Cluster
item.description:
This section describes the detailed steps to import an AWS EKS cluster.

Preconditions

  1. An Access Key & Secret needs to be provided, and its permission policy is as follows:

    {
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "Optimizer",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "ec2:DescribeInstances",
        "ec2:DescribeLaunchTemplates",
        "ec2:DescribeRegions",
        "ec2:DescribeVolumes",
        "ec2:DescribeLaunchTemplateVersions",
        "eks:DescribeNodegroup",
        "eks:ListNodegroups",
        "eks:DescribeCluster",
        "eks:ListClusters"
        "autoscaling:DescribeAutoScalingInstances",
        "autoscaling:DescribeAutoScalingGroups",
      ],
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}

  2. A Kubernetes cluster, version 1.22 and above, EKS cluster is recommended.

  3. A Kubeconfig needs to be provided to access cluster-related information. The permission requirements are as follows (if it is only a development and test cluster without sensitive information, for the sake of simplicity, you can also grant all read-only permissions to the cluster):

    apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  name: optimizer
rules:
  - apiGroups:
      - ""
    resources:
      -nodes
      -pods
      -pods/status
      - persistentvolumes
      - persistentvolumeclaims
      - services
      - namespaces
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "apps/v1"
    resources:
      -deployments
      -replicasets
      -replicationcontollers
      - statefulsets
      -daemonsets
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "batch/v1"
    resources:
      - jobs
      - cronjobs
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch
  - apiGroups:
      - "storage/v1"
    resources:
      -storageclasses
    verbs:
      - get
      - list
      - watch

  4. Prometheus/Thanos address corresponding to the cluster.

  5. The application needs to be able to access the EKS cluster and Prometheus/Thanos.

Import Kuberentes cluster

Add cloud account

  1. Enter the cloud account management page from Settings --> Cloud Account, as shown below.

  2. Click the New button to add a cloud account. You can enter Name, select Amazon AWS as Cloud Provider, then enter Access Key and Access Key Secret, and finally click Confirm.

    After entering the Access Key and Access Key Secret, you can also test whether the access credentials can connect to the cloud provider normally by clicking the Test Connectivity button at the bottom.

Import cluster

  1. Enter the cluster management page from Settings --> Cluster, as shown below.

  2. Click the Import Cluster button and then click on the AWS cloud provider logo to start importing the cluster from AWS. It contains five steps:

    1. Connect to AWS
    2. Connect to kubernetes
    3. Connect to Metrics Server
    4. View configuration
    5. Complete

  3. In the Connect AWS step, select Use existing credentials and select the cloud account created in the Add Cloud Account section, as shown below.

    Then click the Next button to go to the Connect kubernetes step.

  4. In the Connect kubernetes step, select Managed cluster, as shown below.

    First select Region, then select Cluster, and then enter the following configuration items:

    Configuration item Description
    Description Cluster description
    Use private API Server private address Whether to use private API Server address.
    Kubeconfig Kubeconfig to connect to the cluster.
    Automatically refresh Kubeconfig Whether to automatically refresh kubeconfig.
    Node group label Used to identify the node group to which the node belongs. For EKS, the default value is eks.amazonaws.com/nodegroup.

    Note: Since the platform does not use the AWS client to obtain user authentication information, if obtaining user identity information in your Kubeconfig configuration item relies on the aws get token command, you must enable auto refresh Kubeconfig. This ensures that the platform dynamically obtains user authentication details.

    Then click the Next button to go to the Connect Metrics Service step.

  5. In the Connect Metrics Service step, enter the following configuration items as shown below.

    Configuration item Description
    Whether Thanos If the Metrics Server is Thanos, this should be selected.
    Metrics service address Metrics server address, currently supports Prometheus and Thanos.
    Limit access rate Whether to access the access rate limit of the Metrics service address.
    Maximum number of concurrencies Specifies the maximum number of concurrent accesses to the Metrics service address.
    cluster label Used as a label name to filter the cluster’s metrics from the Metrics service.
    Cluster tag value Used as a tag value to filter cluster metrics from the Metrics service.

    Then click the Next button to go to the View Configuration step.

  6. In the View Configuration step, display the configurations for connecting to AWS, connecting to Kubernetes, and connecting to the Metrics service. You can check whether the configuration is as expected.

    After confirming these configurations, you can click the Import button to move to the Finish step.

  7. In the Complete step, the submission status will be displayed, as shown below. When the submission status shows that the cluster has been imported, you can click the Finish button.

Next step

After importing the cluster, you can view optimization suggestions for multiple aspects of the cluster, including:

  • Nodegroup
  • Node
  • GPU node
  • Disk
  • Persistent volume
  • Application

item.title: Docs: Install via Helm
item.description:
This page describes the detailed steps for installing Cluster Optimizer via Helm.

Preconditions

  • Mysql database, version 5.7 and above
  • Kubernetes cluster, version 1.22 and above
  • The certificate of the Kubernetes cluster can create the wiseinf-system namespace and create Deployment, ConfigMap, Service and other resources under this namespace
  • Helm, 3.0.0 and above recommended

Deploy application

  1. Add the Helm warehouse cluster-optimizer through the following command:

        helm repo add cluster-optimizer https://wiseinf.github.io/cluster-optimizer/

  2. Update the warehouse through the following command:

        helm repo update

  3. View the Charts contained in the warehouse cluster-optimizer through the following command:

        helm search repo cluster-optimizer

    The output is as follows:

    NAME CHART VERSION APP VERSION DESCRIPTION
cluster-optimizer/cluster-optimizer 0.1.0 1.1.0 A Helm chart for cluster optimizer

    It can be seen that the warehouse includes a Chart named cluster-optimizer/cluster-optimizer.

  4. Install the demo Chart through the following command:

        helm install demo cluster-optimizer/cluster-optimizer -n wiseinf-system --create-namespace

    Among them, -n wiseinf-system means to install demo under the namespace wiseinf-system, and the parameter --create-namespace means to create this namespace. The output is as follows:

    NAME: demo
LAST DEPLOYED: Thu Mar 28 15:54:42 2024
NAMESPACE: default
STATUS: deployed
REVISION: 1
...

    It means that Helm has successfully deployed the demo Chart.

  5. Check whether optimizer is running normally through the following command:

        kubectl get pods -n wiseinf-system

    The output is as follows:

    NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE
cluster-optimizer-demo-7bfdfdf954-2cgqb 2/2 Running 0 108s
cluster-optimizer-demo-optimizerdb-5d6cdb6b9f-94lc7 1/1 Running 0 108s

    As you can see from the output, Helm has deployed two Pods, of which cluster-optimizer-demo-7bfdfdf954-2cgqb is the Pod of Cluster Optimizer, and cluster-optimizer-demo-optimizerdb-5d6cdb6b9f-94lc7 is the Mysql database it depends on. .

    Note: If you want to use a deployed database, please see [Use Deployed Database](#Use Deployed Database).

  6. Create port-forward to access the optimizer service through the following command:

        kubectl port-forward svc/optimizer 8000:80 -n wiseinf-system

  7. Open the browser and visit the address http://localhost:8000/.

  8. If you can see the Cluster Optimizer homepage, the application Cluster Optimizer is deployed successfully.

  9. You can delete the demo Chart through the command:

    helm uninstall demo

Use deployed database

If you want to use the deployed database and use a new username and password to access Cluster Optimizer, please refer to the following steps:

  1. Open the command line console and clone the installation script to the local computer through the following command.

        git clone https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git

    1. If you use the Gitee warehouse address, you need to replace https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git in the above command with https://gitee.com/wiseinf/setup.git.

    2. The subsequent steps assume that the setup library has been cloned to the user’s home directory. If it has not been cloned to the user’s home directory, the file path in the command needs to be adjusted according to the actual situation.

  2. Execute the mysql command on the command line console to log in to the Mysql database. 127.0.0.1 is the Mysql database host address. You need to replace it with the actual address you use.

        mysql -h127.0.0.1 -uroot

    Note: If you use a remote database, make sure the database is accessible from the Kubernetes cluster.

  3. Create database schema optconf (optimization configuration library) and optdata (optimization database).

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_database.sql

    Note: Please be aware of the risk of data loss. If the optconf library and optdata library already exist in the mysql database, the above script will first delete the library and then create a new library.

  4. Create a new username and password, and set appropriate permissions for them. The username in the script is optimizer and the password is Optimizer~. You can adjust it according to your needs.

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_user.sql

  5. Create the file values.yaml and edit its content as follows:

    optimizedb:
  conf:
    dbHost: 127.0.0.1
    schema:optconf
    port: "3306"
    user: optimizer
    password: Optimizer~
  data:
    dbHost: 127.0.0.1
    schema: optdata
    port: "3306"
    user: optimizer
    password: Optimizer~

    Among them, dbHost is the database address, schema is the database Schema, port is the port, user and password are the username and password respectively.

  6. Install the demo Chart through the following command:

        helm install demo cluster-optimizer/cluster-optimizer -f values.yaml --namespace wiseinf-system

    You can also adjust the database settings by upgrading the original deployment:

        helm upgrade demo cluster-optimizer/cluster-optimizer -f values.yaml --namespace wiseinf-system

  7. Restart the application, check the log output of the Cluster Optimizer Pod (as shown below), and check whether the database configuration information is consistent with your expectations.

    {
    ...
    "optconf": {
        "dataSource": {
            "name": "optimizer:Optimizer~@tcp(127.0.0.1:3306)/optconf?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true\u0026charset=utf8mb4\u0026parseTime=true\u0026loc=Local",
            "maxOpenConns": 10
        }
    },
    "optdata": {
        "dataSource": {
            "name": "optimizer:Optimizer~@tcp(127.0.0.1:3306)/optdata?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true\u0026charset=utf8mb4\u0026parseTime=true\u0026loc=Local",
            "maxOpenConns": 10
        }
    },
    ...
}

    At the same time, also check whether there are any database-related errors. If there are no related errors, it proves that a new database has been used.

Next step: Import the cluster

Next, you can add a cluster and view its related optimization recommendations. For details, see:

  • Import AWS EKS cluster
  • Import Alibaba Cloud Cluster

item.title: Docs: Notification Channel
item.description:
Describes how to manage notification channels, including viewing, adding, updating, or deleting notification channels.

View channels

Enter the notification channel management page from Settings --> Notification Channels, as shown below.

The notification channel management page will display notification channels in the form of a list. It mainly includes 5 columns:

  • Name: Notification channel name.
  • Channel type: Notification channel type.
  • Connection parameters: Displays the connection parameters of this channel type.
  • Other parameters: display other parameters
  • Operation: Operation bar, including editing, deletion and other operations.

Add channel

Click the Add button at the top of the notification channel management page, select the notification channel type, and fill in the notification channel information, as shown below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Name Notification channel name
Channel type Notification channel type, currently only supports Email
Host Email SMTP hostname, for example smtp.wiseinf.com
Port Email SMTP port, such as 25, 465
Enable SSL Whether to enable SSL, the default is not enabled
Email Email address, such as admin@wiseinf.com
Sender name Sender name, e.g. Wiseinf
Password Email SMTP Password
Parameter list User-defined parameter list in the form of key-value pairs. This parameter list will be passed to the template of the notification channel and can be referenced in the template through {{.param.parameter name}}.

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to add the notification channel.

For specific values â€‹â€‹of the above fields, you can consult your email service provider or email system administrator.

Update channel

To update notification channels, click the Edit button in the list of notification channel management pages to update the notification channel information, as shown below.

The specific field names and descriptions are the same as [Add Channel] (#Add Channel) and will not be repeated.

Delete channel

Click the Delete button in the list of notification channel management pages to delete the notification channel, as shown below.

Before deleting the notification channel, a deletion confirmation dialog box will pop up, and the deletion operation will be performed after the user confirms.

Note: When the notification channel is used by notification rules, it will prompt that the deletion was unsuccessful. You should first delete the notification rules that use the notification channel, and then delete the notification channel.

item.title: Docs: Adjust Disk
item.description:
Describes the operation of resizing a disk.

Alibaba Cloud

Prerequisites

TBD…

item.title: Docs: Cluster
item.description:
View connected clusters in the platform.

View cluster

Click Cluster on the left menu bar of the platform to display the cluster overview page, as shown in the figure below.

The main display area will display the list of clusters managed by the platform. Including cluster (cluster name and cluster ID), cluster region, Access Token name, cloud service provider, Prometheus address, health status and other information.

In the commercial version, additional cluster status and operation bars are provided, as shown in the following figure:

Cluster status displays the corresponding status of the cluster to users, making it easier for users to understand the cluster status. Mainly include:

  1. Running: The cluster is running normally.
  2. Sleeping: The cluster is entering sleep state.
  3. Hibernate: The cluster has hibernated. In the dormant state, the cluster has released corresponding node resources, and the cluster usage is limited at this time.
  4. Waking up: The cluster is transitioning to the running state.

In the cluster operation column, users can operate the cluster, including:

  • Set cluster hibernation *Hibernate immediately
  • Wake up immediately
  • log

Set cluster hibernation

Cluster hibernation reduces cluster resource usage and saves costs by properly managing the nodes in the cluster. Assume that the cluster starts sleeping at 9 pm from Monday to Friday and wakes up at 8 am from Monday to Friday (that is, ending hibernation). The machine cost savings can be as high as 54.8%. Setting cluster hibernation allows you to set the sleep time and wakeup time of the cluster. During the sleep time, the status of the load in the cluster is stored, and the node resources in the cluster are gradually released. During the wake-up time, the system gradually restores the node resources in the cluster and restores the original state of the load. Cluster hibernation is especially suitable for offline environments such as development and testing.

Click Set Cluster Hibernation in the operation bar, and the dialog box will pop up as shown below:

Select Enable in the Whether to enable sleep option, then set the specific sleep time and wake up time, and click the OK button. The default sleep time is 9pm from Monday to Friday, and the default wake-up time is 8am from Monday to Friday.

If you want to cancel cluster hibernation, select Disable in the Whether to enable hibernation option and click the OK button.

When the cluster is dormant, the cluster access account provided by the user will be used to operate the cluster. You need to set up a cluster access account. For details, please see Setting up a cluster access account.

Note: The interval between sleep time and wake up time must be greater than 2 hours.

Hibernate now

Move the mouse to ... and click the Hibernate Now button to hibernate the cluster immediately.

Wake up immediately

Move the mouse to ... and click the Wake Up Now button to wake up the cluster immediately.

log

Move the mouse to ... and click the Log button to view logs related to cluster sleep or wake-up.

item.title: Docs: Install the commercial version
item.description:
This page describes detailed steps for installing the commercial version.

Preconditions

  • The community version of the cluster optimization platform has been deployed. For specific installation steps, please refer to [Installation via Kubectl] (/docs/setup/setup-using-kubectl/) and [Installation via Helm] (/docs/setup/setup-using-helm/).
  • To obtain commercial version authorization, you can obtain authorization through the company’s official website or email [Contact Us] (mailto: business@wiseinf.com).

Configure user database

  1. Open the command line console and clone the installation script to the local computer through the following command.

        git clone https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git

    1. If you use the Gitee warehouse address, you need to replace https://github.com/wiseinf/setup.git in the above command with https://gitee.com/wiseinf/setup.git.

    2. The subsequent steps assume that the setup library has been cloned to the user’s home directory. If it has not been cloned to the user’s home directory, the file path in the command needs to be adjusted according to the actual situation.

  2. Adjust the database information in the Cluster Optimizer configuration file. Edit ConfigMap optimizer-conf in the file ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml and add the following configuration items.

    user:
  dataSource:
    name: "root:optimizer@tcp(optimizer-mysql:3306)/user?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true&charset=utf8mb4&parseTime=true&loc=Local"
    maxOpenConns: 10

Configure commercial license

  1. Adjust the database information in the Cluster Optimizer configuration file. Edit ConfigMapoptimizer-conf in the file ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml and add the following configuration items.

    license:
  certificate: {obtained authorization certificate}
  signature: {obtained authorized signature}

  2. Deploy Deployment optimizer through the following command:

        kubectl apply -f ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml

    Note:

    1. If the Pod of Deployment optimizer has not been restarted, please use kubectl delete pod -l app=optimizer -n wiseinf-system to delete the Pod of Deployment optimizer and then re-create it. `
    2. If you want to use a deployed database, please refer to [Use Deployed Database](#Use Deployed Database).

  3. Check the log output and confirm that the Pod status of Deployment optimizer is Running.

System initialization

  1. Open the browser and visit the address http://localhost:8000/init to access the initialization page of the commercial version. Enter the user name, password, email, mobile phone number and other information on the page, and click the OK button to complete the system initialization.

  2. Visit the address http://localhost:8000/user/login, enter the user name and password to log in to the system.

  3. At this point, you have upgraded the system to the commercial version.

Use deployed database

If you want to use the deployed user database and use a new username and password to access Cluster Optimizer, please refer to the following steps:

  1. Execute the mysql command on the command line console to log in to the Mysql database. 127.0.0.1 is the Mysql database host address. You need to replace it with the actual address you use.

        mysql -h127.0.0.1 -uroot

    Note: If you use a remote database, make sure the database is accessible from the Kubernetes cluster.

  2. Create database schema user (user library).

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_user_database.sql

    Note: Please be aware of the risk of data loss. If the user library already exists in the mysql database, the above script will first delete the library and then create a new library.

  3. Create a new username and password, and set corresponding permissions for them. The username in the script is optimizer and the password is Optimizer~. You can adjust it according to your needs.

        mysql> source ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/sql/create_user_user.sql

  4. Adjust the database information in the Cluster Optimizer configuration file. Edit the ConfigMapoptimizer-conf in the file ~/setup/cluster-optimizer/yaml/optimizer.yaml and change the user name and user name in the dataSource.name value under the configuration item user The password, database address and port are adjusted to the corresponding information of the Mysql database.

  5. Restart the application and check the log output of Cluster Optimizer (as shown below) to see whether the database configuration information is consistent with your expectations.

    {
    ...
    "user": {
        "dataSource": {
            "name": "optimizer:Optimizer~@tcp(127.0.0.1:3306)/optconf?createDatabaseIfNotExist=true\u0026charset=utf8mb4\u0026parseTime=true\u0026loc=Local",
            "maxOpenConns": 10
        }
    },
    ...
}

    At the same time, also check whether there are any database-related errors. If there are no related errors, it proves that a new database has been used.

Next step: Import the cluster

Next, you can add a cluster and view its related optimization recommendations. For details, see:

  • Import AWS EKS cluster
  • Import Alibaba Cloud Cluster

item.title: Docs: Notification Rules
item.description:
Describes the details of the management notification rule.

View notification rules

Enter the notification rule management page from Settings --> Notification Rules, as shown below.

The notification rule management page will display notification channels in the form of a list. It mainly includes 5 columns:

  • Name: Notification channel name.
  • Channel type: Notification channel type.
  • Connection parameters: Displays the connection parameters of this channel type.
  • Other parameters: display other parameters
  • Operation: Operation bar, including editing, deletion and other operations.

Add notification rules

Click the Add button at the top of the notification rule management page, and the Add Notification Rule dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

Please see the table below for specific field names and descriptions.

Field name Description
Name Notification channel name
Receiver Notification recipient address, such as admin@wiseinf.com
Notification channel You can select the specific notification channel name through the drop-down box
Scheduling time Set the specific scheduling time of this rule.
Optimization strategy Select a specific optimization strategy
Cluster Select the cluster to focus on
Namespace Enter a namespace name, an empty value will match all namespaces
Department Enter a department name, an empty value will match all department names
Group Enter a group name, an empty value will match all group names
User Enter a username, an empty value will match all usernames
Template ID Template ID name, the default value is default
Parameter list User-defined parameter list in the form of key-value pairs. This parameter list will be passed to the template of the notification channel and can be referenced in the template through {{.param.parameter name}}. Parameters with the same name in the notification channel parameter list will be overridden.

Enter the corresponding information according to the field name and click the OK button to add notification rules.

Update notification rules

To update the notification channel, click the Edit button in the list of notification channel management pages, and the Add Notification Rule dialog box will pop up, as shown below.

The specific field names and descriptions are the same as [Add Notification Rules] (#Add Notification Rules) and will not be repeated.

Delete notification rules

Click the Delete button on the notification channel management page to delete the notification rules.

Before deleting the notification rule, a deletion confirmation dialog box will pop up, and the deletion operation will be performed after the user confirms.

item.title: Docs: Delete Persistent Volume
item.description:
Describes the operation of deleting a Persistent Volume.

Alibaba Cloud

Prerequisites

item.title: Docs: Node Group
item.description:
Describes the node group optimization operations provided by the one-stop cloud native cluster optimization platform (Cluster Optimizer).

View node group

Click the Node Group menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the node group page, as shown in the figure below. The node group page is divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: Select the corresponding cluster.
  2. Query area: List items can be filtered based on owner-related information, node group name, node group ID, etc.
  3. List area: Displays the information of the node group, its current settings and optimization settings.

After the user selects a specific cluster, the list area is divided into 5 columns:

  1. Node group column: Displays the node group name and node group ID.
  2. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  3. Current Settings Column: Displays the current instance type of the node group, whether to automatically expand or shrink, the minimum number of nodes, and the maximum number of nodes.
  4. Optimization Settings Column: Displays the node group instance types intelligently recommended by the platform, whether to enable expansion and contraction, and the recommended minimum and maximum number of nodes.
  5. Operation Bar: Displays the corresponding operations on the node group. ,

Adjust node group

Click the Adjust link in the picture above to open the Adjust Node Group dialog box, as shown in the picture below.

Note: Currently only operations related to adjusting node groups are displayed. Automated actions will be provided in the future, and adjustments can be made automatically after the user confirms the settings.

item.title: Docs: Node
item.description:
Describes node-related information and optimization suggestions.

View nodes

Click the Node menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the node page, as shown in the figure below.

The node page is divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: Select the corresponding cluster.
  2. Query area: List items can be filtered based on the node group name and node group ID.
  3. List area: Displays the information of the node group, its current settings and optimization settings.

The Select Cluster Nodes page looks like this:

The list area display is divided into 5 columns:

  1. Node column: Displays node name, instance ID and region information.
  2. Owner column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  3. Current settings column: Displays the instance type, number of CPU cores, and memory size of the node.
  4. Details column: Displays the information provided by the strategy. For example, for low-utilization node strategies, the average utilization of CPU and memory will be observed and compared with the thresholds set by the platform to help users adjust node instance types.
  5. Operation column: Displays the corresponding operations on the node.

Adjust nodes

Click the Adjust link to open the Adjust Node dialog box, which displays detailed adjustment information and recommended adjustment plans, as shown below.

Note: Currently only the related operations of adjusting nodes are displayed. Automated actions will be provided in the future, and adjustments can be made automatically after the user confirms the settings.

item.title: Docs: Disk
item.description:
Describes disk-related information and optimization suggestions.

View disk

Click the Disk menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the disk page, as shown in the figure below.

Disk pages are divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: Select the corresponding cluster.
  2. Query area: Query the corresponding disk by disk ID, instance ID and node name.
  3. List area: Displays disks, instances, usage and operation columns.

The disk page after selecting the cluster is as follows:

The list area display is divided into 4 columns:

  1. Disk column: Displays the disk ID, device name and creation time.
  2. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  3. Instance column: Displays the node ID, node name and region where the disk is located.
  4. Usage column: Displays disk capacity, maximum utilization, average utilization and last update time.
  5. Operation Bar: Displays the corresponding operations on the disk.

Adjust disk

Click the Adjust link to open the Adjust Disk Size dialog box, which displays detailed disk adjustment information and recommended adjustment plans, as shown below.

item.title: Docs: GPU Node
item.description:
Describes GPU node related information and optimization suggestions.

View GPU node information

Click the GPU Node menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the GPU node page, as shown in the figure below.

GPU nodes are divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: used to select clusters.
  2. Query Area: Used to filter GPU nodes by multiple conditions.
  3. List area: Displays GPU node information, its owner, corresponding configuration and utilization, etc.

After selecting a cluster, the GPU node list area will display a list of GPU nodes that meet the conditions in the cluster, as shown below:

The list area is divided into five columns:

The list area display is divided into 5 columns:

  1. Node information bar: Displays the GPU node name, instance ID and region information.
  2. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  3. Settings bar: Displays the instance type, number of CPU cores, memory size, number of GPUs, and GPU type of the GPU node.
  4. Details column: Displays the information provided by the strategy. For example, for low-utilization node strategies, the average utilization of CPU and memory will be observed and compared with the thresholds set by the platform to help users adjust node instance types.
  5. Operation column: Displays the corresponding operations on the node.

Adjust nodes

Click the Adjust link in the Action Bar to open the Adjust Node dialog box, as shown in the figure below.

Note: Currently only the related operations of adjusting GPU nodes are displayed. Automated actions will be provided in the future, and adjustments can be made automatically after the user confirms the settings.

item.title: Docs: Persistent Volume
item.description:
Describes Persistent Volume related information and optimization suggestions.

View Persistent Volume

Click the Persistent Volume menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the Persistent Volume page, as shown in the figure below.

The Persistent Volume page is divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: Select the corresponding cluster.
  2. Query area: List items can be filtered based on name, PVC namespace, PVC name and policy name.
  3. List area: Displays PV, PVC, policy name, usage, latest update time and operation bar.

The Persistent Volume page after selecting the cluster is as follows:

The list area display is divided into 5 columns:

  1. PV column: Displays the PV name, region, capacity and creation time.
  2. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the PV owner.
  3. PVC column: Displays the PVC namespace and name.
  4. Usage column: Displays the name of the optimization strategy, the usage data provided by the optimization strategy, and the last update time. Currently, the platform includes two optimization strategies: Unused PV and Low Utilization PV. For the Unused PV strategy, its PV usage is empty.
  5. Operation Bar: Displays the corresponding operations on the Persistent Volume.

Delete Persistent Volume

Select the row whose policy name column is Unused PV, and click the Delete link in the action column of the row to open the Delete Persistent Volume dialog box, which displays the Persistent Volume details and recommended solutions.

The dialog box is displayed in the community version as shown below.

In the commercial version, the dialog box is displayed as shown below.

Click the OK button in the dialog box to create a task to delete the Persistent Volume.

Adjust Persistent Volume size

Select Low Utilization PV as the policy name in the Query Area, and the system will only display list items that comply with the Low Utilization PV policy, as shown below.

Click the Adjust' link in the list **Action Bar** to open the Adjust Persistent Volume Size` dialog box, which displays the detailed information of the Persistent Volume and the recommended adjustment plan, as shown in the figure below.

In the commercial version, parameters can be set and then automatically adjusted by background tasks, as shown in the figure below.

After setting the target capacity, whether to keep the original PVC name and whether to delete the original PV, click OK to quickly adjust the Persistent Volume size.

Click the Adjust link in the Action Bar again. At this time, you can view the execution log of adjusting the size of the Persistent Volume, as shown in the figure below.

Adjusting PV will use the cluster access account provided by the user to operate the PV in the cluster. You need to set up a cluster access account. For details, please see Setting up a cluster access account.

Note: If you choose not to delete the original PV, you need to delete the original PV yourself, otherwise you will still bear the cost of the PV.

item.title: Docs: Application / Workload
item.description:
Application details and optimization suggestions are described.

View application

Click the Application menu on the left menu bar of the platform to display the application page, as shown in the figure below.

The application page is divided into 3 areas:

  1. Cluster selection area: Select the corresponding cluster.
  2. Query area: You can query by namespace, load name, load type, container and policy name. Currently, the platform supports resource recommendation, unset resource quota, and memory overflow strategies.
  3. List area: Display name, container, current settings, policy name, details and operation bar. Different policy names will have some differences in the displayed information.

After selecting a cluster in the cluster selection area, the platform aggregates the results of all strategies by default and displays them in a list, as shown in the figure below.

Resource recommendation

View resources and recommend related applications

If the policy name is Resource Recommendation, the list area will be as shown in the figure above. The list area display is divided into 6 columns, which are:

  1. Name column: Displays the payload name, namespace and payload type.
  2. Container bar: Displays the container name.
  3. Owner column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  4. Current Settings: Displays the CPU Request, CPU Limit, Memory Request and Memory Limit of the container.
  5. Details: Display average CPU usage, maximum CPU usage, average memory usage, maximum memory usage, CPU Request recommended value, CPU Limit recommended value, Memory Request recommended value, Memory Limit recommended value, strategy Name and last updated.
  6. Operation column: Displays the corresponding operations on the application.

Adjust resource quota

Click the Adjust link to open the Adjust Resource Quota dialog box, which displays application details, recommended values â€‹â€‹and corresponding adjustment statements.

It is displayed in the community version as shown below.

It is displayed in the commercial version as shown below.

In the commercial version, click the OK button to automatically create tasks and automatically adjust resources.

Resource quota is not set

View applications that do not have resource quotas set

If the policy name is No resource quota set, the list area is displayed as shown below:

The list area display is divided into 6 columns, which are:

  1. Name column: Displays the payload name, namespace and payload type.
  2. Container bar: Displays the container name.
  3. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  4. Current Settings: Shows whether the container’s CPU Request, CPU Limit, Memory Request and Memory Limit have been set.
  5. Details: Displays the recommended value of CPU Request, recommended value of CPU Limit, recommended value of Memory Request, recommended value of Memory Limit, policy name and latest update time.
  6. Operation Bar: Displays the corresponding operations on the application.

Set application resource quota

Click the `Adjust’ link in the picture above to open the Set Application Resource Quota dialog box, which displays application details, recommended values â€‹â€‹and corresponding adjustment statements.

It is displayed in the community version as shown below.

It is displayed in the commercial version as shown below.

In the commercial version, click the OK button to automatically create tasks and automatically adjust resources.

Memory overflow

View memory overflow applications

If the policy name is Memory Overflow, the list area will be displayed as shown below:

The list area display is divided into 6 columns, which are:

  1. Name column: Displays the payload name, namespace and payload type.
  2. Container bar: Displays the container name.
  3. Owner Column: Displays the department, group and specific personnel of the node owner.
  4. Current settings: Displays the memory request and memory limit of the container.
  5. Details: Displays the latest OOM time, recent OOM Pod, number of OOMs, and latest update time.
  6. Operation column: Displays the corresponding operations on the application.

Adjust application memory size

Click the Adjust link to open the Adjust Application Memory Size dialog box, which displays application details, recommended memory limit values, and corresponding adjustment statements.

It is displayed in the community version as shown below.

It is displayed in the commercial version as shown below.

In the commercial version, click the OK button to automatically create tasks and automatically adjust resources.

item.title: Docs: Task Management
item.description:
Describe task management.

Preconditions

  • Only available for commercial version

View tasks

Click the task icon in the menu bar on the right header of the platform, as shown in the figure below.

The task management page is displayed, as shown in the figure below.

The task management page is divided into 2 areas:

  1. Query Area: Task items can be filtered based on policy name, task status and creator.
  2. List area: Displays information such as task names, policy names, configuration items, etc.

In the query area, the policy name currently provides four items: unused PV, application resource recommendation, unused resource quota, and memory overflow. Task status includes running, successful and failed.

The list area display is divided into 6 columns:

  1. Task name column: Displays the task name.
  2. Strategy name column: Displays the name of the strategy.
  3. Task parameter column: Displays the task parameters.
  4. Status column: Displays task status.
  5. Creator column: Displays the creator of the task.
  6. Operation column: Displays operations on tasks, including re-running, canceling execution, deleting, viewing logs, etc.

The creation of tasks is responsible for the corresponding policy, see:

  • Unused PV
  • Application resource recommendation
  • Unused resource quota
  • Memory overflow

item.title: Docs: Configuration
item.description: Describes the configuration parameters of Cluster Optimizer.

item.title: Docs: Manual Operation
item.description:
Describes the cluster optimization operations provided by the cloud native cluster optimization platform (Cluster Optimizer).

Cluster optimization operations mainly include:

  • Adjust node group
  • Adjust nodes
  • Adjust disk
  • …
